course_title: Topics in Afr American Studies: Critical Race Theory
seats: Seats: Maximum Enrollment: 3 / Seats Avail: 0Waitlist Total: 0
class_notes:
(Same as WGS 314 1, PHIL 385 1, HIST 396 1)
How does race manifest itself in law? How does whiteness become a form of property? How do race and gender function in relation to each other? Is Blackness a racialization that is different from the production of other kinds of racial imaginaries? In this course, we will explore various theoretical and philosophical readings on race, gender, and various institutions that are integral in the production of racial technologies and political discourses. We will read works by scholars in law, philosophy, sociology, politics, history, and feminist theory, among other fields through the lens of different forms of the carceral state.
course_description: This course explores one of a wide range of topics pertaining to the African American experience in the fields of human and civil rights, social and literary texts, and the social sciences.
